thread.title: Cindy Crawford pulls kids out of school over chemical concerns
thread.title_full: Cindy Crawford pulls kids out of school over chemical concerns - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Cindy Crawford pulls kids out of school over chemical concerns
text:
John Sciulli Crawford said she didn't ‘feel safe’ knowing high levels of PCBs were found at her children’s school. Cindy Crawford pulled her two children out of their high school ahead of the back-to-school sweep, citing concerns over their health and safety at the Malibu, Calif., institution.
The supermodel, 48, and husband Rande Gerber have taken Presley, 15, and Kaia, 13, out of Malibu High School after testing showed elevated levels of polychlorinated biphenyls in several classrooms.
Routine soil tests apparently found elevated levels of the chemicals, commonly known as PCBs, in window caulking in the rooms. PCBs were banned by Congress in 1976 after it was revealed they could cause cancer and harm the immune and reproductive systems.
"I look 10 years down the line. What if my kid, God forbid, had a problem?" Crawford told Maria Shriver on the "Today" show Tuesday.
cindycrawford via Instagram The supermodel and her husband Rande Gerber decided to pull their children from Malibu High School over health and safety concerns. Enlarge cindycrawford via Instgram Cindy Crawford’s children are Kaia, left, and Presley, right. Enlarge "How could I live with myself, if I knew that it was a possibility, and I still sent them to school there?"
Two Malibu schools, including the one Crawford's children attended, reportedly tested 10 classrooms and found four with PCB levels over the federal limit, according to the morning show report. The school district is planning to remove the caulking in those rooms, but Crawford isn't convinced.
"I don't feel 100 percent safe," she told Shriver.
Visit NBCNews.com for breaking news , world news , and news about the economy
"I think that air testing and wipe testings are a great piece of the puzzle. Unless they're testing every day, how do I know that every day it's safe for my kid?"
Crawford even apparently offered to pay for caulk testing at her children's school.
"This is not a Malibu issue," she said. "This is really an issue in a lot of older schools, and I just think the laws need to be changed."
